Just wanted to let everybody know that we've uploaded a video of the
eye behavior for one of our OCR experiments.

It's in the Files section, "eye.swf".  You'll need the free Flash
player to view it.  The quality is pretty grainy.  The actual images
aren't that noisy.

What you're seeing is the champion network from 800 generations,
looking at "A" and other letters of the alphabet.  Each image is
randomly rotated slightly, either clockwise or counterclockwise, and
the letter position is also randomly transformed.

The eye has a resolution of 7x7 pixels, and can move horizontally and
vertically, as well as being able to zoom in or out and rotate cw or
ccw each time step.  We calculate the number of steps that a given
network gets to look at the canvas based on its size.  This network
has 68 steps to view each image.

It's interesting to note that the eye invariably zooms in on the upper
left portion of the symbol, presumably because this area is unique to
the letter "A".  "N" and "M" have similar peaks, but with smaller
angles.

Anyway, we're continuing to experiment...just thought we'd share some
interesting results.  Let us know your thoughts.

Derek
